labels.text: Though this seemingly empty canvas evokes elements of abstraction and minimalism, it employs the Taoist concept of ‘nothingness’ rather than referencing western art history. The meditative quality in Qiu Shihua’s practice requires patience before the figurative landscape—replete with drifting clouds, trees, and banks—appears behind the veil of white. Qiu trained in traditional landscape ink painting, but after a visit to France in the 1980s he developed a disciplined approach by fusing elements of Impressionism and Taoism to create canvasses that drift between western scenery and Chinese landscape conventions.

Though this seemingly empty canvas evokes elements of abstraction and minimalism, it employs the Taoist concept of nothingness rather than referencing Western art history. The meditative quality of Qiu Shihua’s practice calls for patience from the viewer before the figurative landscape—featuring drifting clouds, trees, and riverbanks—appears behind the veil of white. Qiu trained in traditional landscape ink painting, but after a visit to France in the 1980s he developed a disciplined approach that fuses elements of impressionism and Taoism to create canvases that drift between Western scenery and Chinese landscape conventions.
這張看似空無一物的油畫作品，雖然洋溢抽象及簡約主義元素，但其實是以道家的虛無思想為基礎，而非西方藝術史。邱世華的藝術實踐瀰漫冥想般的氣質，觀者只要耐心細看，自然能夠在空洞的畫布下，發現行雲流水樹蔭的景致。邱氏曾接受傳統山水畫訓練，但在80年代遊歷法國後，發展出一套自成一格的繪畫方式，將印象派與道家元素渾然揉合，作品遊走於西洋風景畫與中國山水畫之間。

images.AltText: Oil painting on canvas. Hidden on what appears to be an unadorned khaki beige canvas are the shapes of mountains and trees, subtly rendered in different shades of beige.
images.AltTextTC: 這幅油彩布本作品，初看恍如一張平平無奇的卡其米色畫布，但其實隱現山巒和樹木的形態，以不同深淺的米色淡然描繪。
